text.tspan: Optimal forward calculation of the Marussi tensor
due to a geologic structure at GOCE height
Leonardo Uieda , Everton P. Bomfim , Carla Braitenberg , Eder Molina
1-Observatório Nacional, Brazil 2-University of Trieste, Italy 3-University of São Paulo, Brazil
Figure 1: View of a tesseroid in the geocentric
coordinate system. Point Q is an integration point.
The observation point P is shown with its local
Figure 2: Sketch of the optimization algorithm.
Adaptative resizing of tesseroids when the distance-
to-size ratio is bellow a certain threshold.
Figure 4: Difference between prism and tesseroid per
relative distance (d/L) to the top of the tesseroid. Red lines
represent the minimum desired error. For tensor components
the distance should be 4-6 times the size of the tesseroid.
Figure 3: Difference between prism and tesseroid along a
profile. Black contours are the relative distance (d/L) to the
top of the tesseroid. White contours are differences of 0.01
New GOCE data requires modeling to take
into account the sphericity of the Earth;
No closed formulas for tesseroids so solve
GLC is slow so there is need to optimize the
GLC approximates the integration by a
Points x are called GLC nodes;
Ku (1977) showed that for g the
distance should be larger than the size
Ku, C.C., 1977. A direct computation of gravity and magnetic
anomalies caused by 2- and 3-dimensional bodies of arbitrary
shape and arbitrary magnetic polarization by equivalent-
point methot and a simplified cubic spline. Geophysics, v. 42,
Need to find the smallest distance
Instead of using high order for all
Keep number of GLC nodes fixed;
Need to know how much is "too close";
Compare effect of tesseroid with prism
Find the size ratio (d/L) that gives
Use size ratio to automatically divide
Used 2 GLC nodes in each direction;
for a tesseroid of size 0.001° X
to 0.01 mGal for g and 0.001 Eötvös
shown) the ratios where the same;
Found a size ratio of 1 for g and 4-6
using fixed size and 6 GLC nodes;
Asgharzadeh, M.F., Von Frese, R.R.B., Kim, H.R.; Leftwich, T.E.,
Kim, J.W., 2007. Spherical prism gravity effects by Gauss-
Legendre quadrature integration. Geoph. J. Int., v. 169, p. 1-11.
Heck, B., Seitz, K., 2007. A comparison of the tesseroid, prism
and point-mass approaches for mass reductions in gravity field
modelling. Journal of Geodesy, v. 81, p. 121 - 136.
Size ratio is different for g and tensor;
Need to assess other sources of error:
Size limit for sphericity to affect;
Distance limit for sphericity to affect;
